thread.title: Australian dollar sent on wild ride as equity rout rattles currencies
thread.title_full: Australian dollar sent on wild ride as equity rout rattles currencies

title: Australian dollar sent on wild ride as equity rout rattles currencies
text:
Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Video will begin in 5 seconds.
Don't play Play now More video Recommended BHP releases full-year profit report
When stock market crashes turn to disaster
Mal Maiden: market flip-flop has its upsides
Stock market heresy
Is my super safe?
Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
ASX crash 'worse than expected' Australian market fell, tried to recover but plunged again in a global sell down that has China at its heart, says BusinessDay columnist Malcolm Maiden.
PT2M42S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings The Australian dollar on Tuesday recovered from a mini "flash crash" the night before that saw it close to dropping beneath US70¢ for the first time since April 2009.
The currency plunged close to US2¢ to US70.5¢ on Monday night in sympathy with a dramatic start to Wall Street trading that saw US equities slump.
But the Aussie rebounded quickly from the drop and in the space of minutes had reached US72.5¢. In afternoon trade on Tuesday it fetched US71.97¢.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia strategist Richard Grace says the dollar got caught up in stock market volatility. Photo: Dominic Lorrimer
"It was probably oversold at that point, but it was just after the Dow opened 1000 points down," Commonwealth Bank of Australia's chief currency strategist Richard Grace said.
Advertisement "It got caught up in the stock market volatility, exacerbated by thin liquidity as participants stepped back to the sidelines."
Despite the Chinese stock markets continuing to haemorrhage value on Tuesday, several of Australia's key trading partners, such as South Korea and Japan, had more stable trading sessions that calmed some of the voracious trading among emerging market currencies.
"This helped offset the negative risk sentiment around the dollar and it has bounced back from that," Mr Grace said.
The dollar was also supported by a rallying ASX, which jumped by as much as 3 per cent.
The Commonwealth Bank is maintaining its forecast of US70¢ by March, and Westpac is forecasting it will be trading at this rate by December.
Global volatility may have set back the imminent US Federal Rate hike, which most analysts were expecting in September or December.
Economists had been expecting the Fed to lift interest rates for the first time in almost a decade in September. But the recent volatility in currency and equity markets has analysts pushing back the date. That in turn has been pushing the greenback lower.
Economists at Barclays now forecast the Fed will now wait until March 2016 to make their move.
"Although we continue to see economic activity in the US as solid and justifying modest rate hikes, we believe the Federal Reserve is unlikely to begin a hiking cycle in this environment for fear that such a move may further destabilise markets," the Barclays Research analysts said.
"Instead, we believe [the Fed] will delay the start of the rate hike cycle beyond September as a means to offset tighter financial conditions while it evaluates the effect of recent volatility."
But the chances of another rate cut in Australia appear to be rising, according to market pricing.
US investment bank Citi on Tuesday reported a surge in bets on a third cut for the year, with interest rate swap markets now showing a 76 per cent chance of a 25 basis point reduction by the November board meeting of the RBA.
This compares with a 48 per cent chance when measured on Friday morning, and a 64 per cent chance of a November cut before the Australian stock market opened on Monday.
The RBA has cut the cash rate rate twice this year, from 2.5 per cent to a record low 2 per cent, and now seems inclined to leave it there.
But UK-based Capital Economics, one of the most bearish forecasters on Australia, says Monday's stock market rout will not translate to weaker consumer demand and business investment.
"While we remain more concerned than most about the Australian economy, we don't think that the recent sharp falls in equity prices will filter through into much weaker investment or consumption," chief economist for Australia Paul Dales wrote in a note on Tuesday.
